title: What will be Robinhood Markets' end-of-day market capitalization on its first day of public trading?
possible_answers: More than $35 billion but less than $45 billion
Robinhood Markets will not trade publicly before 1 September 2021
preds: The trading day is almost over, and it looks like Robinhood will settle around $35 a share, in the $25-35 billion range.
Looks like it'll end in the $25 billion to $35 billion range. There's maybe a 5% chance CNBC's math is wrong, since it's not always clear from the SEC filings how many shares there are.

Robinhood has been trading below its $38 a share opening price, which means it is valued at less than $32 billion. The price at one point even dropped by more than 10%. Adjusting my prediction to increase the $25 billion - $35 billion estimate.
Rather than obsessively watch the stock for the next three hours, I'll just leave my best guess. Have fun!

$38 a share = $32 billion. Source: https://www.cnbc.com/2021/07/28/robinhood-valued-at-32-billion-after-selling-shares-in-ipo-at-38-per-share-source-says.html I didn't know whether it would pop, but so far it's been flat to down, maybe $31 billion in market cap at 12:30 PM. This ups the odds it will end up in the $25 billion to $35 billion range at the end of today.  Personally I'm not very excited about the business or stock and am staying out.. Robinhood was really building a strong future moat with millennials and Gen-Zers before this year, but it seems like the GameStop debacle has done real damage to Robinhood's reputation.

Robinhood is IPO-ing today, and it has been priced at $38 a share, the bottom of the estimated $38-$42 range, leaving it with a valuation of $32 billion dollars. Thus, I update my estimate to give more weight to the $25-$35 billion range.

Set to begin trading today at $38/share. https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/28/technology/robinhood-ipo-share-price.html?action=click&module=In%20Other%20News&pgtype=Homepage That would put it's valuation at $31.7 billion.

Robinhood is officially going public today, so I reduced that probability of it not occurring to zero. The implied market cap before open is $32bln, and given the retail availability of the stock and the typical IPO pop I think the most likely individual node is an increase in value above the current market cap, with a non-negligible chance of a massive jump.
I just discovered that somehow my most recent probabilities were not recprded in my two previous forecasts.

Comparison classes, from today's Wall St. Journal,  https://www.wsj.com/articles/robinhood-ipo-prices-at-38-a-share-11627515866 "Past IPOs in which a significant percentage of shares were allocated to individual investors have struggled. In 2012, Facebook Inc. FB 1.49% sold about 25% of its IPO to individual investors. The stock closed slightly above its $38 IPO price in a rocky first day of trading before tumbling the next day, in part because many individual investors received more stock than they wanted. It took more than a year for Facebook to close above its IPO price again. In 2006, Vonage Holdings Corp. VG 0.56% allowed longtime customers to buy into its IPO. Its stock also wobbled in early trading."

Dateline 7-28-2021 "Robinhood IPO Prices at $38 a Share. The investing platform is expected to start trading Thursday in a highly anticipated deal.... It pegs Robinhood’s valuation at about $32 billion." -- https://www.wsj.com/articles/robinhood-ipo-prices-at-38-a-share-11627515866 The big question is what the price will be at the end of trading tomorrow. Because so many shares are allocated to individual ("retail") investors, and given the history of individual investors manipulating stock prices via mass social media efforts ("meme stonks"),  by the comparison class of Gamestop I expect great volatility.  See also @Hesch at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1311872 for his rationale justifying a higher upside than I am forecassting.

According to Bloomberg Businessweek, Robinhood is targeting an IPO this week (putting the "Not trade publicly before 1 September 2021" option at near-0 probability), targeting a valuation of $35 billion. Bloomberg analysts estimated that the valuation could end up being anywhere from $27 billion to $40 billion, so I adjust my estimate to be centered around $35 billion now.
Based on fact IPO slated for tomorrow, updated my forecast.
IPO officially announced, valuation dropped to seeking 35M.
updating for lower valuation, confirmed ipo

So, they started their valuation estimate with 40. Now it's 35. 
Just looking at it, it shows not so much confidence in the market?! 
Normally the end of day valuation is higher. However, HOOD giving access to retail investors, and letting them to immediately trade 15% of their shares could make the price fluctuation. And the volatility could go either way.  Having said all that, I'm more optimistic, at least in the short term, and will assign higher probability to +35B (4 to 1 ratio, simply based on a hunch; I definitely need to make my approach more robust in the future similar forecasts)

Adjusting down as RH has reported revenue is down and the CFD spread has also taken a big fall.  You can still get a sell contract on the valuation being less than $45bn though https://www.cnbc.com/amp/2021/07/19/robinhood-warns-retail-trading-is-slowing-down-especially-in-cryptocurrencies.html https://www.ig.com/uk/shares/markets-shares/robinhood-ipo-market-cap-bn

Going public is a done deal. Since the target valuation right now is $35B, I'm splitting the valuation equally on either side. By Wednesday we should get a better idea of the valuation based upon the road show and pre-IPO sales. Dateline 7-7-2021 https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/21/technology/robinhood-ipo.html

I am going against the group on this one. I am cagey that there may not be an offering this summer because the SEC is awake but I think Robinhood's happy warriors will take this stock to the moon...on day 1 of trading.

Range that Robinhood is targeting is in the $25-35 billion section.  Bringing that probability way up, with a bit more of a chance to the upside than the downside. "IPO pop" may be difference or non-existent if they are selling a decent chunk of the shares to their users.

As @Hypotanuj mentioned, Robinhood is seeking a 35 billion valuation. According to previous IPO stats, https://marker.medium.com/why-the-day-one-ipo-pop-is-overhyped-85fbab29103b, only 25% of companies saw a decrease in their value, with the median being a 29% rise. Thus, I have made the probability that Robinhood finishes under their 35 billion target about 25%, and the rest have been placed above 35%. 45 billion would be about that 29% pop, but since Robinhood is a well known company, the meme stock nature may cause it to go higher. There is still some chance they don't IPO due to regulatory reasons or market sentiment, although that seems to be very low according to recent releases.

Since Robinhood is begfinning its road show to big investors, the SEC must have given full approval.  I'm retaining a 3% likelihood of no before 1 Sept. on the basis of the comparison class of the Saudi oil IPO, from which they backed off for awhile because the road show couldn't justify the asking price. Since news stories say the asking price is ~$35B, now I'm redistributing probabilities around that price.

Targeting $35B, would need a 29% pop to get over $45B, which wouldn't be super shocking, but is less likely if they're targeting a lower price than the one that had been rumored for months. Outside rate is a pop of 20% with SD of 15%, with some adjustments to account for the likelihood of edge cases since this is so uncertain.

https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/robinhood-aims-up-35-bln-valuation-us-ipo-2021-07-19/
https://www.sec.gov/edgar/browse/?CIK=1783879 Valuation is lower than expected, but doesn’t mean it won’t raise more.  Still, not sure it’ll be as hot as initially expected.  Raising forecasts for lower bins

Robinhood has reduced the IPO value from $40 billion a few months ago to now $32 billion. It's possible there could be a 1st-day pop, so imo $35 billion to $45 billion remains the most likely outcome. Looking at the S-1, I realized their business is perhaps not as good as I previously thought, mainly the fact that 81% of their transaction revenues come from just a few market maker customers. Looking at online sentiment, Robinhood has a lot of hate these days in social media. Even their Glassdoor rating is down compared with the start of this year.

https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/robinhood-aims-up-35-bln-valuation-us-ipo-2021-07-19/
As usual with such announcements, this could mean anything or nothing.  Moving closer around their number anyway, though.
Updating estimates due to time lapsed.

Robinhood is aiming for a $35 billion valuation: https://www.cnn.com/2021/07/19/investing/robinhood-ipo/index.html They've gotten some negative attention lately from Congress and the media, but I still think investors will buy shares. I do think there is a non-zero chance of Robinhood being unable to list before September, but that risk will diminish with time.
largely agree with @tjh475 in their very good analysis. https://edition.cnn.com/2021/07/19/investing/robinhood-ipo/index.html

From their updated prospectus on 7/19/21 (https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/0001783879/000162828021013986/robinhoods-1a1.htm), Robinhood's IPO estimate currently stands ~$35b. Most IPOs tend to outperform day 1, and certain ones tend to go up a large magnitude. $55b + valuation would imply Robinhood trades up more than 50% from its initial IPO price which is not impossible looking at some recent tech IPOs. It seems very unlikely that Robinhood trades down on its first day (reflected in the 1/5 probability of this happening). Overall, seems mostly likely to be up in the 35-55B valuation range as reflected.

This morning, Robinhood released an updated prospectus (https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/0001783879/000162828021013986/robinhoods-1a1.htm#ib5a32e8afc3b422193a2f2891a49e0c9_667), outlining their intention to list just under 836mm shares at a range of $38-42. This would give the company a market cap of $31.8bn-35.1bn after the first day of trading. Historically, IPOs tend to outperform their valuation, due to underwriter incentives to underprice the stock and capture extra profit (https://www.investopedia.com/terms/u/underpricing.asp), so on this basis, I would expect Robinhood's IPO to outperform its valuation by 15-20%, in line with historical norms (https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/trends-in-ipo-pops-2021-03-04). However, given Robinhood's unpopularity with the retail traders that will be making up 20-30% of its first-day shareholders, I would expect the "IPO pop" to be a bit more muted than normal, perhaps more around 10-15% (making the new first-day market cap in the $35bn-39bn range, approximately). The options given here are such that the question itself implies an IPO value of $40bn, so given my hypothesis outlined above, my distribution of outcomes skews to the lower end of the offered ranges. However, I believe the probability of the tail events (< $25bn or > $55bn) tends towards the more optimistic side of things, given how Robinhood offering a significant portion of their shares on their own platform might encourage more casual participants to get involved and curb some less positive action on the stock that may be coming from other retail traders. While these are both relatively extreme outcomes, I'm keeping the probability of each of them relatively high, as Robinhood's association with retail trading - and by extension, the "meme stock" frenzy that has resulted in names like GME and AMC trading at valuations with limited connection to fundamentals - makes it significantly more likely it could get caught up in that same kind of retail action, whether positive or negative - even on its first day of trading. Latest reports per Barron's (https://www.barrons.com/articles/robinhood-ipo-51626693536) and NYT (https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/19/business/robinhood-ipo.html) indicate that the company is preparing to go public at the end of next week, so the probability of it not trading before September 1st has been significantly reduced here.

A few hours ago, Robinhood made an amendment to its S-1 saying that it plans to raise more than $2B and offer 55 million shares between $38 and $42. Given these price bounds, we can estimate Robinhood's market cap to start trading from ~$31.6B to $35B. I estimate there to be a 1% chance that Robinhood drops >21% on its first day of trading, reducing its market cap to less than $25. On the other end of things, I estimate there to be a 1% chance that Robinhood gains >28% on its first day of trading, which would increase its market cap to over $45B. In terms of trading above or below $35B, this is very difficult to predict so I estimate the chances of each at 50%. Robinhood is planning to IPO by the end of next week (Jun 30) and it looks like they have pushed aside any potential roadblocks. Given this, there does not seem like any possibility of Robinhood not trading publicly before Sep 1.

Made a slight adjustment -- I think a $55B market cap if it opens near $35B implies a much higher performance on the first trading day than previous IPOs, so I have lowered the probability of that outcome.

I started with the main ideas in my prior estimate and updated with new information. A prospectus released today has shown that Robinhood is seeking a valuation of as much as $35B in its IPO. Before, my valuation was based around an IPO opening market cap of $40B. Though it is now more likely the opening IPO market cap will be lower, I think the fact that this is announced lowers the uncertainty that it will be below this value, so I have lowered the downward skew and increased the probability for the other categories. I have also lowered the probability that it will not publicly trade as most experts expect the IPO in the next month.

On July 1st, Robinhood publicly filed for an IPO submitting an S-1 registration form to the SEC. The typical time to go from the initial S-1 filing to an IPO is around 3-6 months, however it seems as though Robinhood does expect to be able to go public within the next month or so. But because we are getting closer to the September 1st deadline and even a 1 month expected IPO date puts us close to September, I'm increasing the probability Robinhood doesn't go public before 1 September 2021 while keeping the distribution of the IPO valuations roughly the same.
Four things do not come back: the spoken word, the sped arrow, the past life and the neglected opportunity.—Ted Chiang, The Merchant and the Alchemist Gate
S-1 filed July 1 so we should expect an IPO in 4-6 weeks from that date, they are looking to raise 100m but haven't set an opening/target price yet.

I'm taking a big leap in a different direction on the basis of this analysis https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1303610 by @Hesch. His observation of the time delay from filing with the SEC to going public is especially important.  I also like that @Hesch is a data scientist and Iranian now working in Germany, signs of grit and an ability to navigate the future on a personal basis. Impressive.

SOURCES:
https://news.yahoo.com/robinhood-ipo-filing-caps-stunning-135719465.html
Largest IPO filed in 2021 https://www.marketwatch.com/story/the-5-most-eye-popping-disclosures-in-robinhoods-long-awaited-ipo-filing-11625178338
might have bad rep, it is given more credit than it should depends on dogecoin and market for altcoins
Forecasters predict 30-40B, retail might drive up price but generally expected to fall on first day from opening valuation anyways.
I mainly based on most recent information (https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/01/technology/robinhood-ipo-financials.html) + crowd forecast but I'm not very confident on these estimates

On July 1, 2021, Robinhood officially filed its S-1 with the SEC. It takes 12 to 16 more weeks usually to get all the approvals after this stage. 
https://www.financialexecutives.org/FEI-Daily/March-2018/Going-Public-The-Pre-IPO-Timeline.aspx However, whenever it happens, it's approximated to stand to about 40 BUSD. https://www.ft.com/content/7421d913-0f77-4458-9032-59ba32c846f1
The interesting point is that RB is going to assign about 35% of shares to retail investors. https://www.nerdwallet.com/article/investing/buy-robinhood-stock This could  introduce “a ton of risk and volatility” to the first day of trading since Robinhood has no guarantee those buyers won’t immediately dump the stock. “It could lead to wild trading.” https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/01/technology/robinhood-ipo-financials.html
time decay- IPO likely this week, already has symbol and offering led by GS

Robinhood officially filed for an IPO yesterday, so it's more likely they will trade publicly before September 1. I've adjusted that component of the forecast accordingly. As it regards the other options, I believe I was too optimistic with my initial forecast and changed my predictions to be more in line with a relatively tempered IPO.

“Was kümmert mich mein Geschwätz von gestern, nichts hindert mich, weiser zu werden.” or “I don’t care at all about whatever I said yesterday, as nothing prevents me from getting wiser.”—Former German Chancellor Adenauer

Their IPO already looked like a potential disaster.
They just paid a record $70 million dollar fine to FINRA.
Then they just filed their S-1 with the SEC: https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1783879/000162828021013318/robinhoods-1.htm and they confirmed their many problems. Including losing $1.4 billion on $500 revenue during 1Q 2021. "In its filing documents, the company admits that many of its customers are furious about how it handled January’s GameStop stock bonanza and that it is currently subject of at least 49 class action lawsuits related to trading restrictions it placed on the stock in January. The company also said it is under investigation by a series of regulators, state attorneys general, the SEC, and the U.S. Department of Justice in proceedings associated with the trading restrictions; the company said its CEO Vladimir Tenev has also had his cell phone seized by federal attorneys. " 
https://www.vice.com/en/article/wx5p8z/feds-seized-robinhood-ceos-phone-in-gamestop-trading-halt-investigation I don't know how often the SEC approves an IPO for a company currently under investigation for SEC violations. I think if it does go forward, it has a good chance of bombing, and a small chance investors just don't care about all the problems.

My previous estimate had put the chances of Robinhood not trading publicly before Sept. 1 at 30%, which in hindsight was a large overestimate that didn't take into account the nuances of the situation, as historically the IPO process takes about 4-6 months (https://www.cnbc.com/2019/03/23/heres-what-you-should-know-about-the-ipo-process.html). However, the high volume of SPAC/IPO activity over the last few months have made certain aspects of this process more drawn-out and delayed the SEC's approval process, so I feel comfortable stating there's still a relatively significant chance Robinhood does not trade publicly before September, with now just two months to do so (https://www.etftrends.com/crypto-channel/robinhoods-ipo-review-slowed-down-at-the-sec/). My thought process over its valuation if or when it does IPO, though, remains relatively similar to before.
Bumping last bucket on basis of SEC delays

I've adjusted my predictions by adding more weight to the last option (RH won't trade publicly before 9/1), after the following news: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-06-24/robinhood-ipo-plans-said-to-be-slowed-by-sec-review. The SEC review has slowed down RH's IPO, which was targeted for this month. Bloomberg notes that while the IPO could still happen this summer, it will likely slip into the fall.

https://www.cnbctv18.com/market/robinhoods-ipo-plans-delayed-as-us-sec-reviews-crypto-business-9777171.htm
Will keep a watch on what the SEC has to say

"In its latest funding round, it secured $2.4 billion, giving it a valuation of around $40 billion. That more than triples its September valuation of $11 billion." (June 7, 2021) https://www.valuethemarkets.com/2021/06/07/should-you-buy-robinhood-shares-at-ipo/ "Robinhood wants to time its initial public offering so people will be back from July 4 holiday travel, said the people, who asked to not be identified because the matter isn’t public."  https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-06-08/robinhood-markets-is-said-to-now-target-july-for-ipo Moving the forecast to better account for a 1st day pop. Given the estimated $40B value the 37% average pop last year puts it just below $55B, the 1960-2020 avg pop was 17.2% which puts it at $47B. The wildcard here is since the shares will be made available to retail traders pre-ipo this pop could swing wildly from historical norms. There's also no guarantee they'll set the IPO value at $40B. At $30B it could still cross $45B but its less of a guarantee. Will need to adjust when a price is set. https://tickertape.tdameritrade.com/investing/investing-how-ipo-shares-are-allotted-18656

Current valuation sits at 40bn $. From what we have seen so far this year which I think should be looked at much more heavily than historical data because of changing market conditions, suggest that IPOs do not have a clear directional edge but they seem to have some very large swings this will make our probabilities symmetric and closer to an equal distribution as this volatility is very high. Based on News it seem like the consensus is that the IPO will happen in July, there is not really much news to suggest that an IPO is more or less likely and therefore I doubt I will be changing this probability much unless there is some substantial news

It seems most experts put the initial IPO of the company around 30-35 billion, with the valuation of the company being 11.7 billion last year, and it experiencing rapid growth in the past year due to the memestock and cryptocurrency movements in January. It added 3 million new users in January of 2021 and based on the trend of retail investor growth, it would make sense that it had growth as well later on as well. This doesn't necessarily correlate to an increased IPO, but it seems accurate that it's starting IPO would be approximately 30 million.  RobinHood might have high volatility in its market cap due to its relative infamy in the market due to public backlash in January which, although less now, might be brought back to public light when it IPO's.  Volatility is high but not confident in either direction.

We can first start with estimates of Robinhood's valuation, which currently sits around $40 billion as per multiple estimates from February. This is also a large increase from the estimate of $12 billion from September 2020, which reflects the increased interest in retail trading. It's possible that the valuation increases even further for the IPO considering how much this industry is growing.  Reports on the potential IPO have a target date of mid to late July, and while many companies have been delayed due to the pandemic, considering how controlled the situation is becoming, I find it unlikely it will get delayed by over a month.  We can also see that average returns on first day for IPO's have been around 20% since 1980, but the number for tech IPOs is closer to 35%. However, around 30% of companies also lose money on their first day, according to Forbes. Considering there is a lot of rave about Robinhood and media coverage, we should expect a lot of volatility and variance soon after public release, but I think this would also likely place Robinhood amongst the group of IPO's that make positive returns upon release.

https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/robinhood-ipo-july-target-40-billion-trading-app-valuation-report-2021-6-1030506803 They're eyeing a date, so less chance of no IPO. Valuation's still iffy, every news article seems to be citing secondary market data for a valuation of $40 billion, which is a bit above where I'd estimate it to be but not far off. What their pop (or drop) looks like is the main wildcard.

At its last funding round in February, Robinhood was reportedly valued at around $40 billion, and they are also actively seeking to IPO sometime in early July and as a result, it is unlikely that they won't be able to IPO by September.  Througout all IPOs in 2020, the average IPO pop was somewhere around 38%, however due to skew in the potential gains, the median pop was around 20%, so my best estimate for the average market cap of Robinhood at the end of the first day of trading would be around 48%. However, its also important to take into account that 31% of IPOs actually fall on their first day of trading historically, so there is a significant chance that Robinhood could end up somewhere in the $35 billion - $45 billion evaluation range, with $25B-$35B also being possible but unlikely.

We start off with Robinhood's current valuation, which appears to be roughly 40 billion (https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/robinhood-ipo-july-target-40-billion-trading-app-valuation-report-2021-6-1030506803). Though some IPOs have been postponed because of volatility, it seems to have mostly affected smaller companies. We estimate the last probability as 5%. Rephrasing the buckets as percents loss/gain, our buckets are [-100, -37.5], [-37.5, -5], [-5, 5], [5, 37.5], [37.5, 100]. The average IPO first day return from 1980-2020 was 18% and 2020 averaged 36%. Robinhood is interesting as its relation to meme stocks, and it seems that it has a negative reputation among the r/wsb community. Our baseline will be (18*1/3+36*2/3) = 30. Standard deviation is large (39%) with fatter tails. The last bucket should then be about 45% (from now on, we are conditioning on the ipo happening). The [5, 37.5] represents approximately one standard deviation below, so we estimate that at 10%, to allows for larger tails. Proceeding like this, we use a normal distribution and adjust to have fatter tails.

We have that the CNBC news state that Robinhood is currently valued at $40 billion. The Wealth Daily news raises concern on the brand image of Robinhood after the GameStop event. However, I would argue that this would not be a factor negatively affecting Robinhood's price because people forget about past events quickly, both suggested by both behavioral finance and anecdotal experiences. 
For a commission-free brokerage like Robinhood, the most valuable asset for them is the number of active users and the trading in order for them to stay competitive in their core business of payment-for-order-flow. 
To predict Robinhood's expected market close price, let us compare the following data among Robinhood and several publicly-traded brokers as of Q1 2021: Robinhood: 
Net revenue: $682 million
Users: ~20 million
Trading volume: $350 billion Futu Limited Holdings (FUTU): 
Market Cap: $21 billion
Total revenue: $283.6 million
Net income: $151.7 million
Users: 14.2 million
Trading volume: $289.0 billion Charles Schwab (SCHW): 
Market cap: $137 billion
Users: 32 million
Total revenue: $4.7 billion
Net income: $1.5 billion
Volume: 8.4 million * 252 ~= 2.1 billion (this is # transactions, not in $) FUTU would be a more suitable comparison to Robinhood compared to SCHW, as they both primarily face retail investors. Using the more important metric, trading volume and user, by comparing to FUTU, Robinhood should be priced around $25-30 billion. 
However, if using revenue as the metric, by comparing to both FUTU and SCHW, Robinhood should be priced in the range $18~50 billion. 
Given these two methods, I am more leaning towards the fair value of Robinhood being around $25-30 billion as trading volume and user should be the most suitable data to evaluate on.  At the first day, Robinhood could move towards my predicted fair value of $25-30 billion. More likely, giving present market sentiment and participation of retail investors and extrapolators, Robinhood can be traded higher, likely around 30% of the IPO price, due to its popularity at the first day, and slowly correct to the fair price, as many past IPO stock movements suggest.

A reasonable base rate for RH’s market-cap post-IPO can be found by comparing the post-IPO market-cap performance of similar companies that IPO’d in 2020/2021. The most recent estimate for RH’s valuation in February 2021 was $40B. Considering companies that went public in 2020, the median company that went public saw a 20% price hike on the first day, 25% of companies traded lower than their IPO price, and 28% traded 50% higher. Given that Robinhood is a very “hyped” and polarizing product (given recent news), I’d expect higher variance around its day-of market cap. Using the numbers above, we can get an expected valuation of 50B, with significant likelihood of the 2 neighboring ranges (35-45, 55+) and a slightly larger likelihood on larger valuations because of stellar IPO performance in 2020.

However, I can’t eliminate the chance that they won’t IPO altogether by 9/1/21, especially given other IPOs that have been delayed later that what the public anticipated, i.e. Databricks. Specifically for RH, given the meme-stock frenzy, and their questionable handling of various events, it would not be surprising if the company held off on IPO for a couple months. However, this is less likely because the product is in a very high growth phase right now (with respect to number of users joining the service, due to work-from-home, more easy investing accessibility, reddit frenzy, etc).

To determine Robinhood's market cap on the end of the day of trading, let's analyze two main factors: its current valuation, and the predicted performance on the day of its IPO. We will also consider announcements from Robinhood to determine the probability it does not trade publicly before September 1 2021. Robinhood has announced it will IPO during July, sometime after the July 4th weekend. It also announced it is expanding features such as the ability for customers to buy into IPOs including its own. Although Robinhood has announced its date, IPOs such as Hear.com have been delayed recently due to increased market volatility. Robinhood was valued at $12 billion in September 2020, and $40 billion in February 2021. With the retail investing industry rapidly growing, it is likely that the valuation could be above $40 billion by early July.  After examining typical first day IPO performance, we see that from the 61 companies that IPO'd in 2020, the median company increased its price by 20%. Given these numbers, Robinhood's expected market cap end-of-day would be $48 billion. Further looking at the 2020 IPOs, we see that only 25% of companies traded less than its IPO, and 28% ended the day with over 50% more. Because of Robinhood's prominence in the media, and expanded features for customers to buy into its own IPO, we expect to see a better performance than the average IPO of 2020.

Note, while I believe the vehicle for going public would have an impact on its trading activity on its first day of public trading (i.e. IPOs would limit media influence on information dissemination while SPACs wouldn't, hiring an investment bank might lead to a lower initial listing price to offset the risk of undersubscription), to follow the prompt I'll ignore that factor. According to most reputable sources, Robinhood is currently valued at $40bn from its February 2021 funding round. I don't want to use this number as an "anchor," but think it's an important reference point for a 37.5% drop (25bn) or gain (55bn). I think the first day close will trend higher than the 40bn valuation as there will be little institutional selling given a presumed holding period, and retail investors have been found to trade on the magnitude of news rather than its directionality (i.e. positive or negative) in my brief examination of relevant finance literature in retail investor attention (i.e. Colaco, Hugh M. J. and De Cesari, Amedeo and Hegde, Shantaram P, 2016). Robinhood has certainly been in the news a lot and is a well-known brand. Hence, I've made my estimates more "top-heavy" as while I don't see a plausible scenario in which it trades at lower valuations like 25bn, the flipside is possible (i.e. direct listing for a higher price ~45bn, then buying pressure pushing the stock up by close). To quantify this impact, the average first-day IPO return in 2020 in the US was 36% (https://www.statista.com/statistics/914701/first-day-gains-after-ipo-usa/). Assuming 2021 follows similar patterns and $40bn is a fair valuation at IPO, using this average gain, it would finish first-day trading at $54.4bn. However, this value seems to be an outlier, and the median value before 2020 (which is stable) seems to be around 14% (implying $45.6bn). To add even more nuance, Robinhood interacts directly with retail investors. Due to the meme stock saga, the company's worsening brand reputation and amongst retail investors and evidently weak balance sheet might lead to a lower valuation upon IPOing. As for a delay, while it's certainly possible and happens in financial markets, I believe Robinhood has realized how weak its balance sheet is after the meme stock craze and will likely seek an opportunity to gain equity financing as an opportunity to restructure. They're currently aiming for an early July listing and have been considering a public listing for some time now. A piece of opposing recent precedent to consider is Coinbase (though it had a pre-listing valuation at 140bn, it closed its first day of trading at a valuation of 85.8bn) that might caution against my optimism. However, its 140bn valuation was privately closed at a time where decentralized finance was still relatively hot (and that hype died down really quickly afterwards); thus, I think explains its depreciation.

Firstly, I think it is very likely that Robinhood will IPO before September, as many news articles are projecting the IPO in July, coupled with the fact that Robinhood recently introduced the "early access to IPO" feature which seems like it would be used for the purpose of their own IPO. Additionally, out of the 560 IPOs this year, only a handful have been delayed. Thus, I put the likelihood at 5%.
Next, I found online that Robinhood was being valued around $20 billion last year. Given that the revenue from the first quarter projected for the next full year would be double this year, I would project that Robinhood's valuation would likely be at least $40 billion. 
Finally, I looked at previous IPOs in the last year, and on average for tech related companies, it seems like on average it seems to spike around 30-40% on IPO date. Thus, I predict around $50B for the IPO price, and made the rest of the distribution centered around there, with a fairly wide variance due to macro/market uncertainty and uncertainty on how much it will spike on the first day. It is likely more upward skewed as there were more instances of tech companies spiking on their first day, and looking at P/S ratios like Snowflake's after IPO seem to give evidence of a higher upside.
Robinhood is one of the most popular online brokers right now, and the company is planning to go public later this year.

Most recent information pegs Robinhood at $40bn valuation, with target IPO date of 7/01/21. Given the general positive activity in IPOs recently, along with Robinhood's name recognition, there would likely be decent activity on its IPO, which may favor an uptick in market cap from initial valuation. This is partially countered by the possibility of retail activity in the other direction, given the firm's reputation post-meme stock, but I believe the former forces would outweigh the latter.

Normally, first 3 days there are no sell, and with a hot-IPO such as Robinhood, I expect a range up to 48 BUSD (20% increase).

According to BusinessInsider, Robinhood is aiming for an IPO in July for $40 billion (https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/robinhood-ipo-july-target-40-billion-trading-app-valuation-report-2021-6-1030506803). Since Robinhood has been the center of a lot of attention within the "meme stock" movement (as well as retail trading in general), there is likely to be high interest in its IPO.  Given this level of interest and the fact that the median company out of the 61 IPOs in the US Stock Market saw a pop of 20% on the first day (https://marker.medium.com/why-the-day-one-ipo-pop-is-overhyped-85fbab29103b), it is likely that Robinhood will see a pop of similar size or higher, bringing my estimate to $48 billion or higher.  One concern is that WallStreetBets traders may try to short Robinhood due to its unpopularity there (due to the GME incident in January); however, on the day of an IPO there is likely initially only a small number of shares trading, which means that it will be harder to borrow/short the stock, which may reduce the short pressure (https://www.investopedia.com/ask/answers/05/062905.asp). In aggregate, my prediction is that the bullish interest in the stock will outweigh any WallStreetBets short pressure.  Lastly, IPOs being delayed is not unheard of. Roblox and Affirm delayed their IPOs this past year (techcrunch.com/2020/12/14/ipo-delays-are-bumming-me-out), and last month three companies delayed their IPOs due to a market selloff (https://www.barrons.com/articles/3-companies-delay-their-ipos-after-broad-market-selloff-51620951503). Thus, although Robinhood is aiming to IPO in July, it is a distinct possibility that due to market performance or volatility (or even another PR incident involving Robinhood) that the IPO could be delayed by a month or two.

First, it seems that Robinhood will almost definitely be traded publicly before September 1 2021 and is currently planning for late July.  After that, the last previous benchmark value for Robinhood was $11.7 billion in a privately funded round last year, however this does not include the growth that Robinhood saw in the past year through the pandemic. There estimates that I saw tended to range around $20-40 billion with more recent articles tending to have higher predictions. Additionally, it seems as though Robinhood may trade some shares via direct listing. I think that this will increase the first day retail demand and result in a market share of a little over $40 billion. That being said, there is uncertainty in this amount, and lots of time until they go public which gave me my overall probabilities.

The most recent article published by Forbes regarding the valuation of Robinhood was in April 2021 (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/investing/robinhood-ipo/#:~:text=The%20company%20was%20reportedly%20valued,%2440%20billion%20in%20February%202021). Forbes estimated that the broker was valued at $40 billion at the time of reporting (February 2021). With more than 20 million active users, Robinhood was able to generate $682 million in Payment for Order Flow (PFOF) and continues to generate revenue as retail investors flood to the markets. I predict that Robinhood will most likely end its first day of public trading with a market capitalization of anywhere between 35-55 billion dollars, conditional on Robinhood going public within the next six months. This would represent a forecast of anywhere between -13% to 38% of its most recent valuation by Forbes in February 2021. However, there is the case in which Robinhood will opt to delay going public, and raise more capital/revenue to going public. There is a possibility of this due to the fact that recently Robinhood has been under media scrutiny for recent events related to "meme stocks" and user backlash. Therefore, this must be priced into the distributive model as it is possible that Robinhood will not go public for a duration of time, and therefore also continue to grow its market cap. If Robinhood does decide to go public prior to September 1, 2021, then there also exists the black swan event in which the majority of market participants will decide to short sell Robinhood stock, therefore driving the price down and causing Robinhood's market cap to be less than 25 billion.

Since this is two questions I'll address each individually: Will it IPO before September?
Probably, Robinhood clearly wants to and its in their interest to IPO while the increase in activity from COVID is happening, they've already filed their S1 so they're almost certainly ready. S1 was filed on March 23, meaning they have more than 5 months, and most IPOs are 4 months or less from S1 to IPO. Airbnb was 4 months, and Roblox was 4 months after a delay, and Affirm 2 months after a delay. If everything goes smoothly it should almost definitely IPO before September 1. The two concerns are scrutiny by the SEC under Gensler and pricing issues as we come out of the pandemic and their user numbers become less clear.  Gensler was recently confirmed as head of the SEC, and he does not like Robinhood, he's written about stock picking being like dart-throwing, wants to study Robinhood's behavioral prompts (they recently removed the confetti likely as a response to this criticism, from him and others), as well as whether consumers are getting best execution in a payment for order flow system. Robinhood has been fined for best execution violations in the past (https://www.finra.org/media-center/newsreleases/2019/finra-fines-robinhood-financial-llc-125-million-best-execution). The broader story about Robinhood seems to be one of fast and loose Silicon Valley meeting stricter regulations, and its not clear whether they've cleaned up their act enough since so little is public. Need for study and potential regulatory violations could lead to delays in the IPO process, but I don't think its super likely. Delaying an IPO would be a pretty significant action when the SEC can still impose fines and investigate misconduct regardless. The SEC is also working on ways to get more companies to go public instead of staying private, so an IPO delay would be an odd choice on their part as well. All that said, running afoul of regulators is a possibility nonetheless. The other concern is about getting a good price for institutional buyers. COVID and GameStop have sent Robinhood's user numbers and revenue skyrocketing which has served to inflate its valuation recently, but its unclear if these users will continue to use the app. GameStop is largely over, and there will likely be less trading as a pastime when the pandemic ends. These factors may be concerning to a potential institutional buyer who doesn't want to get into a company while it's riding a temporary high, when they could instead get into it when its numbers become more consistent and predictable (and lower) in the near future. If they meet this kind of resistance in the roadshow process then they may decide to delay the IPO, or the process may take longer than it otherwise would. I would hope that Robinhood has tested the waters for this type of resistance, but it's possible that it'll arise in the future as the pandemic wanes in the US and investors ask for more up-to-date user and volume numbers. It's also possible that Robinhood will make up for some lost demand with their program of getting users into the IPO process. Bets on the IPO prices as mentioned by @Spuerer1 are trading around $55B, so a lot of those users would likely be willing to pay a higher price. Its unclear if they could meet billions of dollars in demand though, since Robinhood users tend to be pretty small.  All those risks together put the chance of not IPOing before September around 17%. It'd be out of the ordinary, but there are legitimate risks that I'll need to monitor.  End of day price?
I break this down into three pieces, which are what's its most recent valuation, what will be the IPO price, and what will be the IPO pop/drop. Most funding rounds are 5-8% of the valuation including for Robinhood's past rounds, and they recently raised $3.4B. This was due to the GameStop frenzy and an urgent need for a lot of capital so they probably sold more than they normally would've. 8% would put the valuation at $42.5B, but I'd guess it's higher at around 10%, putting the valuation around $35B or somewhere in the 30s.  As for the IPO price, its unclear if it would be a markup over that prior round. The investors were the same funds that did their prior rounds, so they may have just been infusing capital to make sure the company didn't blow up during an important moment so it would make it to IPO. In that case they'd probably push less for a markup over that price. It's also possible it was opportunistic buying at a lower price than they otherwise would've gotten, in which case the IPO price would be higher. A markup would probably be around 15% given the short timeline if I had to guess, with a ~50% chance of that markup happening.  Lastly the pop/drop. IPO pops have averaged 20% in 2020, but 25% of IPOs dropped on their first day, so there's a wide range attached. On one hand, Robinhood is a large company with widespread brand recognition as a successful tech company disrupting an industry, so that would favor a big pop as retail traders gain access. On the other hand, the inclusion of users in the pre-public offering may make a "new" higher price less justifiable since a lot of everyday people have already bought the stock at the IPO price, and Robinhood's gotten a lot of very public scrutiny recently around its business model built on PFOF. It's hard to say where public opinion is on them. The r/wallstreetbets crowd is decidedly against them, but the bets on the IPO valuation as mentioned before are ludicrously high. All that makes for a mixed bag, but ultimately skewing a bit negative. I end up estimating the first day pop around 15%, a bit below the base rate.  For getting percentages I did a monte carlo where the most recent valuation is $35 with σ=$3B, 50% chance for a markup over last valuation with a markup size of 15% with σ=3.5%, and finally an IPO pop/drop over the prior price of +15% with σ=15% (so 16% chance of a first-day drop). After removing the 17% for no IPO, that gives 0/10/40/26/6(/17). On its face this distribution seems reasonable, but I'll adjust if anything comes up to suggest changing it.
Spreading out probabilities to account for the extreme overvaluation of stocks in general and wondering when rational valuations might return.

My answer also depends on when the IPO happens -- specifically, financial conditions at that time. Depending on who you believe, things are either fine or super iffy and liable to implode. So that will affect Robinhood's valuation (assuming they IPO at all) as their profitability depends heavily on active trading on the platform.
IPO has not yet been announced. Current expectations are now inflated.

Puzzling crowd forecasts. The idea that Robinhood is going to wait for its IPO is very low probability. I'm just going to go with 0%. This question is how much do you think the stock will be on the recieving end of a GameStop type effort. Here's the key piece of information: "The latest bids in the secondary market for Robinhood shares equate to a valuation of around $40 billion, according to data from Rainmaker Securities. That’s about double the proposed IPO valuation that Reuters reported in December, citing people familiar with the discussions. Robinhood was valued at $11.7 billion in its private fundraising round in September."[1] So, it's doubled twice. Sources I've skimmed say IPO could come as early as this month or as late as May. Suppose the above is correct. What is going to happen between now and the IPO? Does the price collapse? Does it stay stable? Or does it increase? And if it increases, by how much? I'm going to 5% hedge the bottom, in case the above is wrong, if it is right and price of this stock collapses, or the stock market itself takes a dive. Give 10% to current valuation. And do a step up to the highest valuation of 30%/50% for the two highest options. With $1.9 trillion in stimulus in the mix, it's going to be all diamond hands.
